I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Power Sector Improvement 
Project.1  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
2.  Years of neglect since independence have left the Kyrgyz power sector in a state of 
disrepair. Facilities are dilapidated, losses are high, tariffs are below cost-recovery, and financial 
performance is poor. The power sector needs an urgent overhaul before the functionality of the 
system is lost. It needs to improve energy efficiency, energy security, and regional power trade. 
The proposed project is critical to attaining these goals. 
 
3.  The  Kyrgyz  Republic  has  abundant  hydropower  resources.  Over  95%  of  energy 
generated  comes  from  hydropower  plants  (HPPs).  Of  the  total  installed  capacity  of 
3,713 megawatts (MW), 2,950 MW (79.5%) is HPPs and 763 MW (20.5%) is combined heat 
and power plants. While the Kyrgyz Republic is the largest net power exporter of the Central 
Asian Power System (CAPS) by exporting surplus hydropower during summer, load shedding is 
frequent during winter when the river discharge is low. Such a supply pattern calls for regional 
power trade. 
 
4.  Reliable supply is also hindered by (i) high system losses (6% transmission loss and 
26%  distribution  loss  in  2009),  (ii)  inefficient  system  operation  using  obsolete  technology, 
(iii) faults caused by dilapidated equipment used since the Soviet era, and (iv) poor governance 
and financial management. These factors also reduce power exports. Since export revenue is 
used to import costly fuel for combined heat and power plants in winter, reduced summer export 
leads to insufficient domestic supply in winter. 
 
5.  Since nearly 60% of electricity consumption is residential, the performance of the power 
sector directly affects the population. The people’s uprising of April 2010 was partly fuelled by 
public anger over the nontransparent manner in which the tariff was doubled in January 2010 
despite poor supply. Power sector reform that involved unbundling of the vertically integrated 
utility2 in 2001 was expected to boost transparency and efficiency. However, the sector remains 
in poor condition even after a decade. It is now perceived that the recommended industry 
structure may not have been suitable for the Kyrgyz Republic. That there are four distribution 
companies to supply just over 1 million customers is seen as an obstacle to better sector 
performance.  
 
6.  While the entire power sector needs to be modernized, the government places top 
priority on loss reduction and more effective governance. This is not only necessary to improve 
commercial  operations,  but  to  regain  people’s  confidence  in  the  power  sector and  ensure 
stability. To achieve this, the government issued a presidential decree known as the “Fuel and 
Energy Sector Transparency Initiative” on 20 July 2010. Energy security through expansion of 
                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The vertically integrated power company, KyrgyzEnergo, was unbundled into (i) Electric Power Plant Company 
(generating company), (ii) National Electric Grid of Kyrgyzstan (transmission company), and (iii) four distribution 
companies each responsible for a geographic area.

2 
generating  capacity  is  also  a  priority,  but  the  short-term  solutions  are  to  improve  system 
efficiency and reliability, and to increase regional power trade. The strategic vision of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for the Kyrgyz power sector is fully aligned with the government’s 
own strategy. The proposed project has the following components: 
 
(i)  Automated metering and data acquisition system. The automated metering 
and  data  acquisition  system  (AMDA)  will  bring  transparency  to  wholesale 
electricity transactions between the unbundled power companies, and to regional 
power trade. AMDA will eliminate errors and rampant manipulation of metering 
data,  which  are  impossible  to  trace  with  the  current  archaic  technology. 
Commercial loss is estimated at 40% of total system loss. Loss reduction will 
make more power available domestically and improve the financial performance 
of the utilities. Accurate data is crucial to improving commercial performance. 
AMDA will also support regional power trade through (a) meeting the CAPS 
metering accuracy requirement, and (b) eliminating unauthorized exports. 
 
(ii)  Substation rehabilitation. Replacing dilapidated circuit breakers and instrument 
transformers  that  have  reached  their  economic  lives,  are  technologically 
obsolete, or do not meet the accuracy requirement for regional power trade will 
improve the reliability of the system. Since the Kyrgyz system is interconnected 
with the CAPS, rehabilitation increases reliability of the regional system that 
underpins regional power trade. 
 
(iii)  Communications and supervisory control and data acquisition system. This 
component will link seven major substations (estimated) and the control centers 
via optical fiber, enabling the system operator to dispatch more efficiently based 
on real-time data. The supervisory control and data acquisition system (SCADA) 
will reduce technical losses by avoiding overload, and enable faster detection 
and repair of faults. The system improves overall efficiency and reliability of 
Kyrgyz power supply and the CAPS. 
 
(iv)  Study on the settlement mechanism for wholesale electricity transactions. 
The objective is to look at the settlement system, and to recommend actions that 
advance transparency and accountability, and to maximize the benefits of AMDA. 
The component will devise mechanisms to improve the commercial performance 
of the utilities, and to streamline contractual and settlement arrangements for 
regional power trade.  
 
(v)  Corporate  and  financial  management  capacity  building  for  the  National 
Electric Grid of Kyrgyzstan (NEGK).3 This will improve corporate management 
of the transmission company through the preparation of a corporate business 
plan,  including  the  review  of  investment  needs,  operation  and  maintenance 
practices, organizational reforms, internal control, asset revaluation, and cost of 
transmission  service.  Financial  management  capacity  will  be  strengthened 
through the application of the International Financial Reporting Standards and 
appropriate corporate accounting software.  
 
                                                 
3  NEGK is an open joint stock company established under the laws of the Kyrgyz Republic. The government holds 
93.7% of the shares; the rest is traded on the Kyrgyz Stock Exchange and the Central Asian Stock Exchange.

3 
7.  The project fits with ADB’s Strategy 2020 and ADB’s Energy Policy.4 The latter focuses 
on  energy  efficiency,  cutting  fossil  fuel  use,  energy  security,  energy  access,  and  regional 
cooperation. The project also promotes capacity development and governance. It is aligned with 
the government's Country Development Strategy 2009–2011,5 which places high priority on the 
energy  sector.  The  Joint  Country  Support  Strategy  2007–2010, 6  prepared  by  major 
development partners and ADB, supports the Country Development Strategy. Although the 
energy sector was initially assigned to other donors, ADB decided to reengage in the sector to 
contribute to the large financing need. The project forms part of the energy strategy agreed 
under the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The project will boost energy security, energy efficiency, and regional power trade. The 
impact will be stronger reliability of the national and regional power systems in the Kyrgyz 
Republic and Central Asia. The outcome will be higher operational efficiency of the utilities. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
  1.  Physical 
 
9.  The  AMDA  will  be  a main  output.  It  will  allow  obtaining  commercial  metering  data 
automatically from (i) about 190 substations of NEGK, and (ii) facilities of the Electric Power 
Plant  Company 7  with  direct  supply  to  distribution  companies  and  interconnections  with 
neighboring countries. A second output will be the rehabilitation of circuit breakers, and current 
and voltage transformers in over 50 selected substations of NEGK. A third output will be the 
SCADA that links seven major NEGK substations (estimated) and control centers. 
 
  2.  Nonphysical 
 
10.  The  main  outputs  will  be:  (i)  project  management  of  physical  investments; 
(ii) recommendations  on  the  settlement  mechanism  for  wholesale  electricity  transactions 
including  the  industry  structure;  and  (iii)  development  of  NEGK's  corporate  and  financial 
management capacities, and strategic business planning.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The project has two executing agencies: MOE and NEGK. MOE is responsible for 
(i) managing  the  study  on  a  settlement  mechanism  for  wholesale  electricity  transactions, 
(ii) managing the capacity-building advisory service for NEGK, and (iii) supervising NEGK's 
project implementation performance.  
 
14.  NEGK  is  responsible  for  managing  the  capital  investment.  A  procurement  capacity 
assessment revealed that the country procurement system is weak and NEGK’s capacity is also 
limited. The existing project implementation unit (PIU) will oversee the execution of the capital 
investment, but project management will be outsourced to an international consulting firm to 
assist  NEGK.  Its  task  will  include  outline  design,  preparation  of  bidding  documents,  bid 
evaluation, contract award, construction supervision, accounting, safeguard monitoring, and 
reporting to the government and ADB. Contractors’ contracts will have fixed prices and fixed 
delivery periods, with premiums and penalties on performance and quality. The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
15.  ADB conducted technical due diligence on the proposed investments and is satisfied 
with the rationale, technical specifications, quantities, and cost estimates. The AMDA is a critical 
technology that brings transparency to the wholesale electricity market, and helps reduce loss 
and boost efficiency in commercial operations. The SCADA is a standard modern utility practice 
considered appropriate to improve NEGK’s system operations. The obsolete circuit breakers 
and instrument transformers need to be replaced with modern equipment to avoid collapse of 
the power system. ADB has confirmed that NEGK has experience in successfully installing and 
commissioning  similar  types  of  equipment  as  to  be  procured  under  the  project.  Stronger 
reliability will improve energy security and boost regional power trade. The AMDA and SCADA 
are a technological step change from the current practice. Training will be included in the project 
management  consultants’  terms  of  reference  and  contractors’  contracts.  The  contracts  will 
include sufficient spare parts, support service, and quality and performance warranties. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
16.  A  financial  analysis  has  been  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Financial 
Management and Analysis of Projects.9 All financial costs and benefits have been expressed at 
constant 2009 prices. Cost streams used to determine the financial internal rate of return—
capital investment and operations and maintenance—reflect the cost of delivering the estimated 
benefits. The financial internal rate of return is 7.83%, which compares favorably with the 
weighted average cost of capital (0.65%). Financial viability was gauged by comparing the 
incremental costs and benefits in "with project" and "without project" investment scenarios. The 
incremental benefits come from fewer outages, fewer technical and commercial losses, and 
more domestic and international sales.  
 
17.  The economic viability takes into account streams of costs and benefits resulting from 
the project. Regional economic benefits are not included in the economic internal rate of return 
calculations since they accrue to countries other than the Kyrgyz Republic.  Other unquantifiable 
benefits are lower operation and maintenance costs, more efficient dispatch based on reliable 
real-time data and historical data, better water management at Toktogul HPP through loss 
reduction. The economic internal rate of return is 24.41%, which compares favorably with the 
12% opportunity cost of capital.10  
 
C.  Governance 
 
18.  ADB's Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and NEGK. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM. ADF grant and loan funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s 
Loan Disbursement Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
19.  A  financial  management  assessment  including  risk  management  assessment  was 
prepared in accordance with ADB guidelines. A procurement capacity assessment was also 
conducted.  Similar  to  the  country’s  weak  public  financial  management,  NEGK’s  financial 
management capabilities are also weak. Internal control is lacking, and adherence to accounting

standards,  disclosure,  and  auditing  requirement  is  insufficient.  Building  up  financial 
management capabilities, corporate business planning, and development of human resources is 
critical to improving corporate performance. 
 
20.  To bolster the corporate and financial management capacities of NEGK and to ensure 
governance in project-related activities, the project will include the following measures: 
 
(i)  strengthening the existing PIU and maintaining separate project accounts; 
(ii)  outsourcing project management to an international consulting firm; 
(iii)  establishing  a  direct  payment  procedure  and/or  commitment  procedure  for 
disbursements to contractors and consultants; 
(iv)  having the project accounts audited by an external auditor; and    
(v)  contracting consultants to develop NEGK's corporate and financial management 
capacities,  introduce  the  International  Financial  Reporting  Standards,  and 
prepare a corporate business plan. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
21.  The general population will benefit from a transparent, accountable, and efficient power 
sector. Since the rural poor are the first to be cut off from supply during winter power shortages, 
system loss reduction and stronger supply reliability will particularly benefit the poor and the 
socially  excluded.  Advisory  services  funded  by  the  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development will promote the establishment of an escrow account to ensure that revenue from 
power exports in summer will be used to purchase fuel for stable domestic power supply in 
winter.  The  project’s  advisory  service  on  a  settlement  mechanism  for  wholesale  electricity 
transactions will support efforts by the United States Agency for International Development.  
 
22.  The investments take place in existing substations and transmission lines. There are no 
adverse social impacts except nominal crop compensation during installation of optical ground 
wire (OPGW) at the existing transmission towers. Since the investments only require minimal 
civil works, an influx of workers is not expected.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
23.  The geographic coverage is national. Physical investments are limited to (i) installing 
meters  and  equipment  in  existing  substations,  and  (ii)  stringing  OPGW  over  existing 
transmission towers and laying underground optical fiber cables under public roads in urban 
areas. An environmental and social safeguard specialist will be hired. 
 
24.  Environment category B. An initial environmental examination has been prepared in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).11 The major anticipated impact on 
the  environment  will  come  from  the  disposal  of  electrical  equipment.  The  environmental 
monitoring  and  management  plan  of  the  initial  environmental  examination  requires  the 
transformer oils to be treated in NEGK's oil treatment facility and reused. An official inventory on 
usage of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) does not exist. The environmental monitoring and 
management plan provides guidance on PCB testing, and handling and disposal procedures in 
case it is identified. The project will work closely with the new “Management and Disposal of 
PCBs in Kyrgyzstan” project of the United Nations Development Programme, which is the first of 
its kind in the Kyrgyz Republic. Sulfur hexafluoride (SF ), a potent greenhouse gas, will be used

25.  Involuntary resettlement category B. Project investments will be implemented mostly 
in  existing  substations  where  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  (LAR)  impacts  are  not 
envisaged. Work space and access is required only for stringing OPGW over the existing 
transmission towers to develop a modern communication system. The towers are mostly on 
farmland.  Very  limited  temporary  LAR  impact  such  as  crop  losses  during  installation  is 
expected. Since the exact location of the work space can only be identified during detailed 
design and temporary works planning by the turnkey contractor, a LAR framework has been 
prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  and  Operations  Manual 
F1/OP.12 The LAR framework has been disclosed on ADB’s website. The turnkey contractor’s 
contract  will  explicitly  state  that  a LAR  plan  must  be  drafted  by  the  turnkey  contractor  in 
accordance with the LAR framework. The LAR plan will be finalized by the PIU and project 
management consultants, and submitted to ADB for endorsement. On-site installation works 
shall not begin until the endorsed LAR plan is fully implemented. 
 
26.  Indigenous  peoples  category  C.  The project is not expected to affect indigenous 
peoples as defined under ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement. The project covers most of the 
country. The majority of the population is Kyrgyz; ethnic minorities comprise Kazakhs, Russians, 
and Uzbeks. These ethnic groups do not differ in their needs or levels of power supply, and all 
will benefit equally from the project. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
27.  Technologies adopted under the project conform to international standards and best 
practices that are commercially proven and widely used across the world. Technical risks are 
low, and NEGK has experience with developing and maintaining similar rehabilitation projects 
funded by development partners. The AMDA and SCADA are new to NEGK, but adequate 
training,  support  and  warranties  will  be  included  in  the  contractor’s  contract.  Project 
management consultants will ensure proper implementation with regard to quality, quantity, 
cost,  duration,  safety,  safeguards,  financial  management,  internal  control,  reporting,  and 
auditing. Capacity building at NEGK and inclusion of sufficient spare parts will mitigate operation 
and maintenance risk.

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
29.  The government and NEGK have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and financing documents. 
 
30.  The government and NEGK have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the draft financing agreement and project agreement.14  
 
31.  No  withdrawal  shall  be  made  until  after  a  subsidiary  loan  agreement,  in  form  and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, has been duly authorized, and executed and delivered on behalf 
of, the government and NEGK. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
32.  I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  and  grant  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR11,010,000  to  the  Kyrgyz
